name: Sandalwood
description: Sacred fragrant heartwood used extensively in Buddhist incense, meditation, and rituals. Its calming, cooling scent aids concentration, purifies the mind and environment, and is believed to attract enlightened beings.
uses: Meditation incense - calms mind, deepens concentration
Prayer beads (mala) - sandalwood malas aid mantra practice
Sacred paste - ground sandalwood mixed with water for tilak marks
Buddha statues - precious statues carved from sandalwood
Funeral rites - burned to guide consciousness in bardo
Temple fragrance - burned daily to purify sacred space
rituals: Daily puja - sandalwood incense essential temple offering
Meditation practice - burn before and during sitting
Blessing ceremonies - anoint with sandalwood paste
Abhisheka - anoint Buddha statues with sandalwood water
sacredSignificance: One of three sacred incenses (with agarwood and clove). Fragrance attracts bodhisattvas and dakinis. Buddha's body said to emanate sandalwood fragrance. Cooling nature calms passions, aids meditation. Supreme offering to Triple Gem.
culturalContext: Mysore sandalwood (Karnataka, India) most prized. Critically endangered due to over-harvesting. Australian sandalwood (S. spicatum) sustainable alternative. Temple-quality sandalwood extremely expensive. Adulteration common - pure sandalwood rare.
preparationMethods: Incense: burn wood chips or powder on charcoal
Sacred paste: grind wood with water on stone to make paste
Mala beads: carve from heartwood for meditation
Powder: grind aged heartwood to fine powder for offerings
Hydrosol: sandalwood water for anointing and cooling

growingConditions.conservation: Critically endangered - cultivation and sustainable harvest essential

symbolicMeanings: Precious = dharma treasures beyond worldly wealth
safetyWarnings: generally safe for external use and aromatherapy
pure essential oil expensive - beware adulteration
